College Cup Group Stage Review

09/06/2013

As the College Cup quarter finals approach, Dan Holland takes a look at how the tournament has progressed so far

Image by

By undefined undefined

Group A

Cup qualifiers - Halifax 1sts, James 3rds Plate qualifiers - Wentworth 2nds, Derwent 3rds Vase qualifier - Langwith 1sts Aside from the runaway winners Halifax firsts, this group was incredibly tight - only one point separated second and fifth place, with Langwith firsts finding themselves in the unusual position on Monday of a win sending them into the Cup but anything else taking them into the Vase. Halifax's dominance was to be expected and they completed their task reasonably comfortably, Alex Tringham impressing and Tom Day finding his shooting boots on the JLD. With the other five teams so evenly matched it was always going to be tough to predict how the rest of the group would finish. James thirds' one and only win against Wentworth seconds proved to be the decider - Ameer Alhasan's side performed consistently throughout the tournament, but it would have been Derwent thirds going through to the Cup had they not been deducted points. Their win over Langwith firsts provided one of the most dramatic moment's of the Cup so far with a last-minute penalty miss, the low point for a Langwith side who have struggled with player availability. Halifax will naturally harbour hopes of lifting the Cup this year, and should make it past Vanbrugh seconds and into the semi finals, though they will most likely be Group A's only representatives there with James thirds facing the daunting task of their own first team in the last eight.

Group B

Cup qualifiers - James 1sts, Vanbrugh 2nds Plate qualifiers - Derwent 2nds, Wentworth 1sts Vase qualifier - Alcuin 3rds With a couple of strong second teams in this group, some people might have expected James firsts to come under more pressure than they did. But the form they showed to rip apart their opposition early in the contest set Josh Spurling's team on their way to five wins from five. The records came and went for Tom Clarke, who had hit a Fantasy Football record number of goals after just three games, while James Davies has been his chief conspirator with 10 assists so far. They weren't quite as dominant in their final two matches though, and we'll have to wait until the semi finals to judge exactly how good this James team are in comparison to their rivals, presuming they get past James thirds. Vanbrugh seconds were deserving runners up after some consistently strong displays, including arguably the match of the tournament so far as they drew 3-3 with Wentworth firsts. The postgrads suffered from the familiar problem of not being able to put their strongest 11 on the pitch every week - had they been able to do so then their early defeats at the hands of James and Derwent could have been much closer. Derwent paid the price for drawing with Alcuin thirds in their opening match, but might be a good bet for the Plate if they play as well as they did against James this week. It was no surprise to see the two thirds teams battle it out for the Vase, but Alcuin's draw with Derwent and the fact that they shipped nine fewer goals made them deserving qualifiers.

Group C

Cup qualifiers - Goodricke 1sts, Halifax 2nds Plate qualifiers - Alcuin 1sts, Vanbrugh 3rds Vase qualifier - Langwith 2nds Halifax seconds would have topped this group were it not for their points deduction. Alongside a demolishing of Langwith seconds, they edged their way into the Cup quarter finals with a series of strong results, Connor McCoy leading the way with seven goals. Despite losing to Halifax, it was Goodricke firsts who ultimately topped the group on 12 points. The likes of Dan Gorringe and Chris Osborne impressed for the Hes East side, and a solid back four with Stu Dunk and Luke Parker at centre half saw them concede just once. Alcuin firsts will no doubt be disappointed with a Plate spot, after Chris Boyd's side struggled to score enough goals with star man Graham Kimber ruled out through injury for the majority of the competition. Tom Chadwick impressed up front, scoring possibly the goal of the tournament so far with his strike against Halifax, though they are also set to be without him for the Plate. Alcuin are joined by last year's Plate runners-up Vanbrugh thirds, who continued their fine form on the JLD from 2012. Below them, Langwith seconds and Wentworth thirds both suffered with ever-changing squads, with Langwith's solitary win over the postgrads enough to take them into the Vase.

Group D

Cup qualifiers - Vanbrugh 1sts, Derwent 1sts Plate qualifiers - James 2nds, Halifax 3rds Vase qualifier - Goodricke 2nds In the end, Group D finished more or less as expected - but that doesn't quite tell the whole story. The showpiece fixture of the Group Stage turned into something of a farce, with Vanbrugh firsts' victory over Derwent firsts not quite the statement it should of been given the bizarre nature of that game. The defending champions topped the group with a 100 per cent record without ever looking imperious (aside from their 10-0 over Langwith thirds, they didn't score more than twice in a game). Derwent, similarly, haven't set the world alight yet but both sides can be expected to up their game for the knockout stages, going into their respective quarter finals as favourites to progress. James seconds were still in with a chance of making it three James sides in the Cup on Friday, but couldn't overcome either of the first teams in the group. They will fancy their chances of a run in the Plate though after some good displays that clearly put them a class apart from the three sides below them. Halifax thirds take the other Plate spot after beating Goodricke seconds, who could be dangerous in the Vase if their squad doesn't change too drastically. Langwith thirds' points deduction was ultimately immaterial as they would have finished bottom of the group regardless.

Group Stage Stats

Top Goalscorer - Tom Clarke (13) Top Assists - James Davies (10) Most Clean Sheets - Halifax 1sts (5) Top Fantasy Football scorer - Tom Clarke (61) Fantasy Football League Leader - Jonny Sim (265) Biggest win - 12-0 (James 1sts vs Goodricke 3rds)
